Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Exploiting Fine-grained WiFi Signals for Wellbeing Monitoring

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
While proliferating WiFi networks are usually used for wireless Internet connections, they have great potential to capture environment changes and identify human motions of various scales. Examples of such motions range from performing daily activities to breathing and heartbeat during sleep. These various scales of motions can be captured by fine-grained WiFi signals to perform continuous wellbeing monitoring. Wellbeing monitoring leveraging existing WiFi infrastructure is particularly attractive as it requires neither wearing body instrumentation nor active monitorng by the user. Such an approach would facilitate a broad range of healthcare related applications at home environments without frequent hospital visits, such as real-time prediction and prevention of certain health problems (e.g., cardiovascular diseases and sleep apnea). Using existing WiFi infrastructure for wellbeing monitoring not only advances and extends the applications that could be supported by WiFi networks but also enables easy and large-scale deployment in non-clinical settings due to the proliferation of WiFi networks. Additionally, the educational efforts include curriculum development, outreaching to high school students, and engaging both undergraduate and graduate students in research.

This project focuses on building a WiFi enabled continuous wellbeing monitoring framework for fine-grained sleep monitoring and vital signs tracking at home environments. Users do not need to wear any sensors or actively participate in the monitoring process. The proposed framework targets to advance techniques in device-free fine-grained sleep events identification and vital signs tracking during sleep by utilizing existing WiFi signals. The proposed framework develops device-free localization strategies, vital signs tracking methods and statistical learning techniques to depict a comprehensive picture of users' wellbeing. Such wellbeing information is further utilized to assist in real-time disease prediction by leveraging today's ever-growing mobile environments. A hierarchical multivariate logistic regression model is developed to effectively mine through health conditions and identify risk factors of certain diseases. Chances of developing certain health problems, such as cardiovascular diseases, is promptly predicted. The project also provides user-centric access control of archived wellbeing monitoring information to ensure data privacy and coping with distrusted servers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project pursues the vision of a system that utilizes device-free localization strategies, vital signs monitoring methods, and statistical learning techniques to depict a comprehensive picture of users' wellbeing. We build a WiFi-enabled passive continuous wellbeing monitoring framework for activity recognition, gesture recognition, sleep monitoring, and vital signs tracking at home environments. Such wellbeing information is further utilized to assist in real-time disease prediction by leveraging today's ever-growing mobile environments. A hierarchical multivariate logistic regression model is developed to effectively mine through health conditions and identify risk factors for certain diseases. Chances of developing specific health problems, such as cardiovascular diseases, is promptly predicted.

The framework we build advances the techniques in device-free activity identification and wellbeing monitoring in the following four aspects: (1) CSI from off-the-shelf WiFi devices is extracted with a much smaller set of WiFi transmitting devices for device-free activity tracking. (2) The identified representative activities performed daily at home reflect a person’s wellbeing including breathing rate and heart rate that contain important information for certain health problem prevention. (3) A hierarchical multivariate logistic regression model is developed to effectively measure health conditions and identify risk factors of certain diseases.  (4) The project provides user-centric access control of archived activity related data to ensure data privacy and coping with untrusted servers.

Exploiting the prevalence of WiFi infrastructures to enable device-free in-home activity identification leads to breakthroughs in continuous wellbeing monitoring without requiring users to wear any radio devices or sensors. This project provides strong evidence of using the WiFi network to capture environmental changes. It also provides new insights in developing suitable data analysis and mining techniques for comprehensive wellbeing monitoring of users’ daily lives. Major research results have be disseminated to academia and industry through paper presentations and publications in conferences and journals (e.g., MobiCom, MobiSys, SenSys, UbiComp, CHI, and TMC). The project has enabled three graduate students (one each from Rutgers, NYIT, and Florida State) to collaborate with each other and to gain experience with the challenges of building the wellbeing framework. The research results have been integrated into both the undergraduate level course "CIS4360 Introduction to Computer Security" and graduate level course "CIS5900 Wireless and Mobile Computing". Moreover, we dismiss and discuss our research findings in the departmental event "CS EXPO" and departmental seminar, where we invite researchers from both academia and industry to give talks about cutting-edge research topics each year. These events enable us to present research findings to students, faculty and experts from industry.
